channel.title: Arab Revolution – Baraza
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: “Sumeida’s Song: Giving Operatic Voice to Revolution in Egypt”
item.dc:creator: Hani Omer
item.description: “Egypt is heading towards civil war”, composer Mohammed Fairouz plainly states in discussion of his opera, Sumeida’s Song, which premiered at the Prototype Festival in SoHo. Civil war is perhaps too strong a word to describe the current state of affairs in Egypt, but few would argue with Fairouz that the … Continue reading “Sumeida’s Song: Giving Operatic Voice to Revolution in Egypt” →

item.title: Watch the Throne: The Moroccan Monarchy’s Mic Check
item.dc:creator: Chantal James
item.description: This July Morocco celebrated Throne Day, in celebration of King Mohammed VI’s ascension to the throne thirteen years ago. He seems to have much to celebrate; time and again, the crown asserts itself as secure against threats large and small. What has been the Moroccan monarchy’s secret to maintaining power in a post-Bouazizi world, when … Continue reading Watch the Throne: The Moroccan Monarchy’s Mic Check →

item.title: Global Unrest Ushers in New Crises of Representation: Assessing the Present and Future of Area Studies
item.dc:creator: barazaonline
item.description: The global wave of protests presently underway has ushered in a new crisis in the interdisciplinary field of area studies. The Arab Spring in particular has sounded an alarming wake-up call, leading many to challenge the relevance of modalities and methods currently employed within area studies. There is an existentialist quality underpinning this crisis, as … Continue reading Global Unrest Ushers in New Crises of Representation: Assessing the Present and Future of Area Studies →
